exonerate.meaning_1: verb: pronounce not guilty of criminal charges
exonerate.sentence_1: The document clearly indicated that Nick was out of the state at the time of the crime, and so served to exonerate him of any charges.

exacting.sentence_1: Though his childhood piano teacher was so exacting, Max is thankful now, as a professional pianist.

intransigent.meaning_1: adjective: unwilling to change one's beliefs or course of action
intransigent.sentence_1: Despite many calls for mercy, the judge remained intransigent, citing strict legal precedence.

pedantic.meaning_1: adjective: marked by a narrow focus on or display of learning especially its trivial aspects
pedantic.sentence_1: Professor Thompson was regarded as an expert in his field, but his lectures were utterly pedantic, focused on rigorous details of the most trivial conventions in the field.

copious.sentence_1: In midsummer, there are copious popsicle stands at the beach; in the winter, there are none.

reconcile.sentence_1: Peggy was unable to reconcile her kind friend Jane with the cruel and merciless character Jane played on television.

unscrupulous.sentence_1: In the courtroom, the lawyer was unscrupulous, using every manner of deceit and manipulation to secure a victory for himself.

admonitory.meaning_1: adjective: serving to warn; expressing reproof or reproach especially as a corrective
admonitory.sentence_1: At the assembly, the high school vice-principal gave the students an admonitory speech, warning them of the many risks and dangers of prom night.

bumbling.meaning_1: adjective: lacking physical movement skills, especially with the hands
bumbling.sentence_1: Within a week of starting, the bumbling new waiter was unceremoniously fired.

espouse.meaning_1: verb: to adopt or support an idea or cause
espouse.sentence_1: As a college student, Charlie espoused Marxism, growing his beard out and railing against the evils of the free-market.

blatant.meaning_1: adjective: without any attempt at concealment; completely obvious
blatant.sentence_1: Allen was often punished in school for blatantly disrespecting teachers.

ingratiate.meaning_1: verb: gain favor with somebody by deliberate efforts
ingratiate.sentence_1: Even though Tom didn't like his new boss, he decided to ingratiate himself to her in order to advance his career.

pundit.meaning_1: noun: someone who has been admitted to membership in a scholarly field
pundit.sentence_1: Steven Pinker's credentials are unquestioned as a pundit; he has taught at MIT and Stanford, teaches at Harvard, and has published a number of influential books on cognition, language, and psychology.

Magoosh Practice Exams.meaning_1: noun: Determine how you'd do on an actual GRE exam by taking a practice exam. Learn more at http://gre.magoosh.com
Magoosh Practice Exams.sentence_1: Magoosh practice exams enabled Margarette to get a sense of what taking the GRE on test-day would be like.

discrete.meaning_1: adjective: constituting a separate entity or part
discrete.sentence_1: What was once known as Czechoslovakia has since split into two discrete, independent nations.

burgeon.sentence_1: China's housing market is burgeoning, but some predict that the growth is merely a bubble and will burst much like the U.S. real estate bubble of 2008.

eradicate.sentence_1: I tried eradicating the mosquitos in my apartment with a rolled up newspaper, but there were too many of them.

tortuous.meaning_1: adjective: marked by repeated turns and bends; not straightforward
tortuous.sentence_1: Because the logic behind McMahon's side of the debate was so tortuous, his audience came out either completely confused or, worse, feeling they'd been tricked.

denigrate.meaning_1: verb: charge falsely or with malicious intent; attack the good name and reputation of someone
denigrate.sentence_1: Count Rumford denigrated the new theory of heat, demonstrating that it was wholly inadequate to explain the observations.

decorum.meaning_1: noun: propriety in manners and conduct
decorum.sentence_1: "You will obey the rules of decorum for this courtroom or spend the night in a jail cell," said the judge to the prosecutor.

ostentatious.meaning_1: adjective: intended to attract notice and impress others; tawdry or vulgar
ostentatious.sentence_1: Matt wanted to buy stone lions for front of the house, but Cynthia convinced him that such a display would be too ostentatious for a modest house in an unassuming neighborhood.

idiosyncrasy.meaning_1: noun: a behavioral attribute that is distinctive and peculiar to an individual
idiosyncrasy.sentence_1: Peggy's numerous idiosyncrasies include wearing mismatched shoes, laughing loudly to herself, and owning a pet aardvark.

petulant.sentence_1: Although the three year old was often described as mature for his age, he was petulant and whiny whenever his father forgot to remove the crust from his sandwiches.

acerbic.sentence_1: Most movie critics are acerbic towards summer blockbusters, often referring to them as garbage.

opaque.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
opaque.meaning_1: adjective: not clearly understood or expressed
opaque.sentence_1: The meaning of the professor's new research was opaque to most people, so no one asked any questions.

indifference.meaning_1: noun: the trait of seeming not to care
indifference.sentence_1: In an effort to fight indifference, the president of the college introduced a new, stricter grading system.

expound.meaning_1: verb: add details or explanation; clarify the meaning; state in depth
expound.sentence_1: The CEO refused to expound on the decision to merge our department with another one, and so I quit.

incorrigible.meaning_1: adjective: impervious to correction by punishment
incorrigible.sentence_1: Tom Sawyer seems like an incorrigible youth until Huck Finn enters the novel; even Sawyer can't match his fierce individual spirit.

adamant.meaning_1: adjective: refusing to change one's mind
adamant.sentence_1: Civil rights icon Rosa Parks will forever be remembered for adamantly refusing to give up her seat on a public bus--even after the bus driver insisted, she remained rooted in place.

myopic.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
myopic.sentence_1: The company ultimately went out of business because the myopic managers couldn't predict the changes in their industry.

laudable.sentence_1: To say that Gandhi's actions were laudable is the greatest understatement; he overthrew an empire without violence.

ignoble.sentence_1: In 1919, the World Series was rigged--an ignoble act which baseball took decades to recover from.

soporific.meaning_1: adjective: inducing mental lethargy; sleep inducing
soporific.sentence_1: Although the professor is brilliant, his bland monotone gives his lectures a soporific effect.

iconoclastic.sentence_1: Jackson Pollack was an iconoclastic artist, totally breaking with tradition by splashing paint on a blank canvas.

provincial.meaning_1: adjective: characteristic of a limited perspective; not fashionable or sophisticated
provincial.sentence_1: Maggie's enthusiasm about her high school teams seemed provincial to her college classmates, all of whom were following a nationally ranked college team.

hackneyed.meaning_1: adjective: lacking significance through having been overused
hackneyed.sentence_1: Cheryl rolled her eyes when she heard the lecturer's hackneyed advice to "be true to yourself."

exalt.sentence_1: The teenagers exalted the rock star, covering their bedrooms with posters of him.

largess.sentence_1: Uncle Frank was known for his largess, so his nephew was sad when he did not receive a present for his birthday.

underscore.meaning_1: verb: give extra weight to (a communication)
underscore.sentence_1: While the hiking instructor agreed that carrying a first aid kit could be a good idea under certain circumstances, he underscored the importance of carrying enough water.

construe.meaning_1: verb: interpreted in a particular way
construe.sentence_1: The author's inability to take a side on the issue was construed by both his opponents and supporters as a sign of weakness.

implacable.meaning_1: adjective: incapable of making less angry or hostile
implacable.sentence_1: Win or lose, the coach was always implacable, never giving the athletes an easy practice or a break.

implausible.meaning_1: adjective: describing a statement that is not believable
implausible.sentence_1: The teacher found it implausible that the student was late to school because he had been kidnapped by outlaws on horseback.

abstruse.sentence_1: Physics textbooks can seem so abstruse to the uninitiated that readers feel as though they are looking at hieroglyphics.

refute.meaning_1: verb: prove to be false or incorrect
refute.sentence_1: No one could refute his theories or propositions, and that is why he was esteemed by all his colleagues in the philosophy department.

confound.sentence_1: Though Harry loved numbers, calculus confounded him.
confound.sentence_2: Americans often confound sweet potatoes with yams, and refer to both vegetables by the same name.
confound.meaning_2: verb: mistake one thing for another

forthcoming.sentence_1: The President announced that the senators were about to reach a compromise, and that he was eager to read the forthcoming details of the bill.
forthcoming.sentence_2: As a husband, Larry was not forthcoming: if Jill didn't demand to know details, Larry would never share them with her.
forthcoming.meaning_2: adjective: at ease in talking to others
forthcoming.meaning_1: adjective: available when required or as promised

pragmatic.meaning_1: adjective: guided by practical experience and observation rather than theory
pragmatic.sentence_1: Rather than make a philosophical appeal to the Congressmen, the Speaker decided to take a far more pragmatic approach, making small side-deals that would add votes to his bill.

temperance.meaning_1: noun: the trait of avoiding excesses
temperance.sentence_1: Welles wasn't known for his temperance--he usually ate enough for two and drank enough for three.

contingent.sentence_1: A small contingent of those loyal to the king have gathered around the castle to defend it.
contingent.sentence_2: Whether the former world champions can win again this year is contingent upon none of its star players getting injured.
contingent.meaning_2: adjective: dependent on (usually used with upon)
contingent.meaning_1: noun: a gathering of persons representative of some larger group

apocryphal.sentence_1: The web is notorious for sandwiching apocryphal stories between actual news.

aberrant.meaning_1: adjective: markedly different from an accepted norm
aberrant.sentence_1: When the financial director started screaming and throwing food at his co-workers, the police had to come in to deal with his aberrant behavior.
